title: 109_s3128
content: The Act titled "National Uniformity for Food Act of 2006" aims to establish national uniformity for food regulations. The National Uniformity for Food Act of 2006 aims to establish national uniformity for food regulations by amending section 403A of the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act to ensure that state requirements for certain foods are identical to federal requirements. The National Uniformity for Food Act of 2006 seeks to establish national uniformity for food regulations by ensuring that state requirements for certain foods are identical to federal requirements. States can enforce identical requirements to federal law if the Secretary has issued regulations or guidance, and must conform to them if no regulations or guidance exist. The National Uniformity for Food Act of 2006 allows states to enforce policies based on identical requirements in state law to federal law. If the Secretary rejects a proposal for regulation or guidance, states cannot enforce any requirements that were rejected. Additionally, the Act amends Chapter IV to ensure uniformity in food safety warning notification requirements. Chapter IV of the National Uniformity for Food Act of 2006 is amended to redesignate sections and insert a new section for uniformity in food safety warning notification requirements. SEC. 403B of the National Uniformity for Food Act of 2006 focuses on uniformity in food safety warning notification requirements. SEC. 403B of the National Uniformity for Food Act of 2006 prohibits States from establishing their own food safety warning notification requirements unless they are identical to those prescribed under the Act. The National Uniformity for Food Act of 2006 prohibits States from creating their own food safety warning notification requirements unless they match those outlined in the Act. The term 'warning' for food indicates a potential health or safety hazard, and any notification requirement for a warning should not be confused with other food safety regulations. The National Uniformity for Food Act of 2006 restricts States from implementing their own food safety warning notification requirements unless they align with the Act. This does not prevent States from carrying out their own notification, disclosure, or dissemination of information related to food adulteration under State statutory requirements identical to those in the Act. The National Uniformity for Food Act of 2006 restricts States from implementing their own food safety warning notification requirements unless they align with the Act. States can petition the Secretary for an exemption or national standard within 180 days after the date of enactment. The National Uniformity for Food Act of 2006 prohibits States from enforcing their own food safety requirements unless they comply with the Act. States can request an exemption or national standard from the Secretary within 180 days of the Act's enactment. If a State submits a petition within this timeframe, the notification or food safety requirement will remain in effect, and specific time periods and provisions will apply. The National Uniformity for Food Act of 2006 allows States to request exemptions or national standards from the Secretary within 180 days of enactment. The Secretary must take final agency action on the petition within 360 days after the public comment period. If a State submits a petition, the notification or food safety requirement will remain in effect until a specified date. The National Uniformity for Food Act of 2006 allows States to request exemptions or national standards from the Secretary. The effective date of the final rule for an approved petition is provided, with no ending date for State law provisions included in the final rule. The final rule does not establish any conditions regarding the provision of law. Noncompliance by the Secretary with timeframes constitutes final agency action for judicial review. If the Secretary fails to comply, the court will order compliance. The court can order the Secretary to comply within a specified period if final agency action is not taken on a State petition. Exemptions and national standards are addressed in the final rule. The Secretary may grant exemptions from certain requirements of the State or its political subdivision under specific conditions to protect important public interests, ensure compliance with federal laws, and not overly burden interstate commerce. The Secretary may grant exemptions from State requirements to protect public interests and interstate commerce. States can petition the Secretary for national standards on food regulations, with a public comment period. The Secretary must take final agency action on a petition within 120 days after the public comment period ends. If not possible, the Secretary must provide reasons and a timeline for the action. Expedited consideration is given to petitions involving notification requirements for food. The notification requirement for food includes warnings related to cancer, reproductive or birth defects, and information for parents to limit exposure to toxins. Failure to comply with this requirement can be reviewed judicially. The court can order the Secretary to comply with requirements if there is a failure to do so. States can establish requirements to address imminent health hazards if certain conditions are met. The State must enforce requirements within 30 days of establishment, and the Secretary must take final agency action on petitions within 7 days. Failure to comply can lead to judicial review. The Secretary's compliance with requirements constitutes final agency action for judicial review. Failure to comply may result in a court order for compliance. State requirements remain until final agency action. This section does not affect product liability or certain state laws. No Effect on State Law - This section does not prevent States from enforcing requirements related to freshness dating, labeling, inspection, dietary supplements, or food sanitation. In section 403A and this section, definitions for 'requirement' and 'petition' are provided. A conforming amendment is made to section 403A(b) of the Act. The requirements of section 403B(c) paragraphs (3) and (4) shall apply to any petition described in section 343-1(b), in the same manner and extent. The Secretary of Health and Human Services must certify to Congress, after consulting with the Secretary of Homeland Security, that the amendments in this Act will not increase the risk of terrorist attacks on the food supply for them to take effect.
